messages.text:
Hey everyone ğŸ‘‹ I have two questions to the round:
1. We wanted to run a bunch of experiments for governance and different token models as part of future projects in the Ocean Protocol Ambassador program to explore and experience how beneficial they are on a small scale with a group of people that want to solve a task together.
Would this overlap with your intentions?
2. For DataUnion - a decentralised, crowdsourcing platform for machine learning ready data - we want to let the contributors get involved in turning the knobs of the system in terms of rewards as well as to determine what will be developed next but we have no real experience which kind of governance model would be most beneficial. To get more info on that we want to create a simulation based on TokenSpice.
Would this overlap with your intentions?

Sorry for directly starting with some questions and maybe you are not at that point yet to answer them, I just found your project and thought I wanted to look for synergies as the space is very wide and difficult to manoeuvre.
Hey Robin! Thanks for asking ~ weâ€™re still early in the process, but Iâ€™d say the answer to both questions would certainly be yes ğŸ™‚

messages.text:
The other thing I think that would be worth researching is aspects such as workers rights. Or contributors rights... Is compensation fair when multiple contributors spend time working on one issue and the first or best get compensated. Time is money and should be treated that way from the perspective of a contributor. 

ICs way around it is by contacting a WG leader before starting on an issue to get permission. This helps a fairer way to contributors and compensation.

text:
Thatâ€™s a really interesting topic! Contributors definitely have rights, although taken for granted...

Like you said, open-source projects and their communities often expect people to work voluntarily or just *in hopes* of earning rewards. Permissioning can help, but of course, time (and energy) spent applying for a role is valuable â³

One thing about Index Coop that stands out is how their Treasury Committee is dedicated to these values:

1.

- Members should feel like the rewards they are given are fair and proportional to the contribution they have made.
2.

- The treasury should be spent wisely for the community and goals of the community.
3.
- The rewards system should take into account multiple types of contributions and varying depths of contributions.
â€œConsistent & transparent rewards are important for acknowledging valued contributions.â€

Hey everyone ğŸ™Œ,  my name is Michael and I am working on a voting module for deliberative decision-making based on argument trees. It is called ArborVote (
). Would be great to join the next call and be part of the governauts.
Hi
my team at
is working on integrating several voting modules and services into a digital voting standard. Want to chat sometime and see if it might be useful for ArborVote?

Here's a draft description of the standard:

Scope and Usage
A vote is a formal indication of a choice between two or more candidates or courses of action. A digital voting service is an internet service that allows users to create, configure, and run a vote, usually on a hosted platform. A voting API is a way of exposing a digital voting service to other web applications.

The voting standard described here is designed to (1) help developers build applications and governance systems on top of a standard voting API, without having to commit to or integrate with a specific software service and (2) help voting services integrate with new users and new platforms via Metagovâ€™s existing libraries. 

This standard comes with: 
mappings from a number of existing voting services into the standard API,
[TBD] a client-side Python library (pip install metagov, import

) that implements and wraps the standard API so that you can create and query votes directly in Python, and 
[TBD] a hosted version of the standard API at

.

At the bottom of this document, there is also a checklist to help voting services conform to the standard and to write their own mappings, as well as some examples of the kinds of applications that the voting standard enables.

text: Not sure if anyone here would be interested but thinking of working on this bounty in the Boardroom hackathon. I'm trying to build a DAO to fund and govern AI models and apps built on top of the Ocean data marketplace.

messages.text: Feedback or collaboration very much welcome ğŸ˜
Cool! That sounds like a really interesting project ~ how are you thinking about requirements?

Haven't thought too much yet. Very early thoughts are that we want a place for data scientists that we onboard to come and have a say in the building of the eco system, how to direct funds etc. It would also give a layer of transparency for treasury, deliverables (to give more confidence on grants that we bring in from OceanDAO). What else should we be thinking about?
What kinds of decisions will the DAO make? Who are your stakeholders? Why should data scientists participate?
How can those decisions impact all types of stakeholders?
Which assumptions need to be reconsidered?

â€œThe creation and distribution policy of UNicoins seeks to be data driven, utilizing user data and meta-data of UNicoins issuance, institutional distribution, transfer, validation, and storage for policy optimization.â€

ğŸ¦„ğŸ¦„ğŸ¦„

Metrics:

â€¢ Cross-UN collaboration tasks categorized by the SDGs (1-17)
â€¢ Affiliated UN Entity or Entities of personnel requesting UNicoins enabled task(s)
â€¢ Expected deliverables within a task
â€¢ Quality assessment and validation of submitted tasks
â€¢ Validation of number of hours submitted
â€¢ Metadata showing exchanges of UNicoins and their circulation across the UN system

Unanswered Questions:

â€¢ How should UNicoins be created and by whom?
â€¢ How can UNicoins be used as a transformative enabler to shift to the Next UN and not to reinforce malpractices in the current UN system? What mechanisms need to be in place to do so?
â€¢ How can the concept and spirit of UNicoins as a way to enable peer-to-peer collaboration, exchange and learning be upheld and the possibilities for UNicoins to be abused or misused minimized?
â€¢ How to ensure that UNicoins do not add to any precarious working conditions of staff?
â€¢ How to ensure that UNicoins incentivizes increased collaboration between teams and agencies? Rather than having a stifling effect (e.g. team leaders or agencies start requiring / demanding UNicoins for collaboration with others)

text: Hey guys very honored to be a part of this group thank you
for the invite

Great insights and hit directly on the issues we are exploring as we move into prototype stage. To address some of your questions: 
- The fixed exchange rate against an hour of time is based on the Japanese fureai kippu, meaning caring community. As time is inherently equal to all of us it is non-inflationary and thus maintains value. In the fureai kippu (FP) model voluntary service to assist elderly is recognized by FP tokens that are denominated in one hour increments. As we

will become old those who give service in youth can redeem them upon needing them later. This, one could argue it is not pure volunteering but a redemption specific form of time banking. 
- In our prototype we will airdrop UNicoins to users based on a self reported number of hours that have already provided to UN system in a limited period of retroactively (I.e 6 month prior). As we are a closed system this can be validated. Going forward we are looking at a few models such as having UN entities buy them at cost recovery rates, mint based on our prototype assessment of hours in circulation to maintain optimal monetary policy, burn for inactivity, and other models. We will test various theories of change in prototype period. 
- To foster transformative best practice is part based on the metrics / data strategy to ensure optimal quality. Initiatives will need to budget time and link to deliverables and SDG outcomes. Redemption post deliverable is assessed for quality with community input to rate impact. 
- To mitigate abuse is two fold the approval process of creating an initiative is based on a hierarchical meritocracy that requires users with high number of validated hours to approve projects. Budgets are capitalized from users accumulated UNicoins.
- To avoid precarious working conditions the UNicoin activities should be voluntary. Though exploring policy that would allow all staff to volunteer up to 5% of their work time, which offers them career exposure. 
- To ensure collaboration every initiative has to have users from other UN entities (limiting collusion). Exploring minimum of three and various levels from each, which is similar to interagency working groups. 

Would really enjoy discussing in further details in Governaughts working groups for community input on how to optimize further as the prototypes start materializing

The basic gist is simply to do a weighted vote streaming, but where you can also recursively fund similar "honeypots" that act as sub-orgs within the DAO

messages.text: Streaming = continuous feedback + teams being incentivized to be massively transparent about their work and communicate with high quality

Fractal = modularize the voting, people can vote in specific areas of the project, top level DAO voting can be very high level, whereas people in the design honeypot (for example) can vote more granularly.  Also, it allows suborgs to define their own governance, which helps localize failure/blowup

messages.text: Nice! Iâ€™m curious to learn how youâ€™re thinking about overlap between such impact DAOs and service DAOs from the other list you shared
Hello! I'm interested as well in exploring new ways of organizing people and better forms of money.

Impact DAOs are the non-business actors of the space, while service DAOs provide services for other DAOs (DAO2DAO) Product or protocol DAOs (a possible third category) build independently governed tools or web3 infrastructure.
District0x was one of the first product DAOs, but now the best example is DXdao
RaidGuild is the prime example for service DAOs
and I think maybe MolochDAO is the oldest impact DAO, focusing on critical Ethereum development
The intersection of service and impact DAOs are really desired as it's basically about DAO public goods

Question for the community: can and should governance be a new IP category?
Intellectual Property or Internet Protocol?
Intellectual property.
Who would enforce crypto governance IP?
I donâ€™t think itâ€™s possible or desirable
Imagine if ancient Greece tried to paywall democracy
Very interesting question! What exactly do you mean by governance in the context of IP?

Thank you for exploring this idea with me. My own thoughts are not very mature so I thought this might be a good place to discuss this idea. 

Well, when I boil it down the main network IP is licensed under an open source agreement. That means it canâ€™t be the equity in the economic system. The trademark may also be representative of the value of the network but that doesnâ€™t explain enough the perceived value. As a result, a regulator can only determine if the token is a security or commodity based in the degree of decentralization in rendering the service and decision making. This is why some have suggested a sandbox approach to crypto wherein the network can take up to three years to decentralize both facets. 

However, decentralization can also be viewed as the component corresponding to the value of the token in a non-arbitrary way. Much like a process patent, one could imagine patenting the governance system which gives way to decentralization. It wouldnâ€™t just be a happenstance process but an element of the networkâ€™s design. 

As intellectual property the governance patent would benefit from all the existing international agreements making it a much more robust differentiator between networks.
Great expression of this!
Yes, absolutely! Many forms, much diversity and variance, it's an area for study all of its own. I find it fascinating!

I need your help to understand the â€œproposal inverterâ€ ğŸ™ƒ

How does it compare to another DAO managing continuous allocations?

messages.text: Imo the coolest parts of this are the fact that other brokers can join in to the pool with general certainty that if another "payer" doesn't hold up their end of the bargen, they can force quit and get their funds back.

And seems like even if there is churn among the payers/brokers, the initial agreement can continue as long as new brokers are found within the time specified (as long as x epochs have not passed that allows for a forced exit)

So, as someone who is receiving the funds, or the initial payer, there seems to be a variety of ways to keep the agreement open, but if brokers cannot be found, forced exit is a viable option. Seems like an interesting use-case for when multiple DAOs want to fund some work to get done. They can all put up some allocation of funds, but if there is churn among the DAOs, the DAOs can either put up more funds, or new DAOs can enter as brokers to keep the agreement going. 

Although, not sure I quite understand the logic here: "A payer takes the action pay by providing a quantity of tokens (split into Stablecoins and DAO tokens) "

Not sure why there's stablecoins and DAO tokens ğŸ˜…, but this may be specific to some platform and not as "generalized"?

messages.text: Should be interesting and relevant to governance, especially in diving into how decentralized applications are used to fight fraud and corruption while increasing trust and transparency in IFADâ€™s operations.
Metasystems ...

Hmm... I would maybe step back and first, categorize & qualify the type of DAO before going into any discussion.

Double-majority seems to be suggesting some sort of democratic, legislative process, and with for an example: a protocol grants DAO, that governance may not exist. 

I.E. Coin voting dictates funding outcomes, but hold no power in ratifying core team direction.

DAOs do vary considerably, DAO culture varies as much as in the old corpo system ...

That Twitter discussion is interesting in that folk will decide what and when to invest, but may also need to decide when to divest, and how and why.

Yes, the term DAO is too broad. 

It's like talking about food while analyzing a banana. 

Yes, it's food, and a fruit, but if we are trying to understand a banana, maybe we should go as far as a plantain, before going back up on the evolutionary branch.

Phylum > Genus > Species
What I love is that it's possible to dive in and experience the culture first hand ...

messages.text: hey everyone! what do you think about the connections of reputation systems and reward system? Is reputation a type of reward? Are only monetary rewards considered legitimate? Is reputation too close to punishment?

text:
on the one hand, Iâ€™ve definitely been in environments where Iâ€™m doing a lot of work for non-financial reasons. so if I had a way to codify/track that, thatâ€™d be great. but at the same time, i might want to track it for my own reference and not for others knowing (e.g. when I donate funds, I donâ€™t like listing my name) so thereâ€™s the interesting component of is tracking reptuation around certain activities creating new forms of social incentives around those activities just because others want to â€˜game the systemâ€™ now. 

in terms of legitimacy, I think as long as something is seen as legit, itâ€™s legit. if no one cares about reputation in a community, prob not a legit way to reward. that could easily hit a tipping point where all of a sudden people want that reputation, which would make it legit. Iâ€™m really excited to see more experiments that try to systematize non-financial reptuation (I like Nathan Schneiders recent paper on cryptoecon as a limitation on gov -

)

the reputation as punishment is one Iâ€™ve been thinking of more and more. I do think thereâ€™s a big difference between promoting and rewarding good behavior vs explicitly penalizing bad behavior. itâ€™s a fine line but I see a big diff between trying to encourage pro-social/positive behavior within a system vs openly chastizing or punishing people for bad behavior. makes me think of Libertarian Paternalism by Thaler and Sunstein (

Choices / Considerations:

- What is the goal of the evaluation?
- Who will design and conduct the
evaluation?
- When will the evaluation be conducted?
- What system or component(s) will be
evaluated?
- Where will the evaluation occur?
- What are the factors and groups of interest?
- Which additional factors will be accounted
for and how will they be accounted for?
- How will the evaluation dataset be created?
- Which performance metric(s) will be used?
- How will performance be analyzed?
- How transparent will the evaluation be?

"Although disaggregated evaluations can add
urgency to normative debates about AI systems, there are many
other considerations beyond performance that can determine a

messages.text: In legal structures one speaks of a bundle of rights that convey various user rights to assets. Each right in this bundle of rights can be unpacked and be assigned to parties, be them at the individual, collective, municipal, national, regional or international level. The risk of dispute between various parties generally grows commensurate and proportional to the degree of complexities involved both vertically and horizontally. In governance the optimal design solution is to separate and allocate those bundle of rights at the onset in a harmonious manner to mitigate tensions, leaving any residual tension to be resolved through informal and formal channels of dispute resolution.

Few initial reactions:
- Blockchain may be agnostic but there is an argument to be said that the consensus protocol of Ethereum is â€œneoliberalâ€ in the sense that it is highly dependent on market theory, while not asking if the particular market mechanisms used for validating transactions is optimally effective and efficient. Increased competition from alternative decentralized networks may ultimately answer that questionâ€¦
- Focus on antitrust/anticompetitive behavior open up the point on legally wrapped DAOs. Emerging legislation to offer DAOs may drive standards driven by antitrust principles if those DAOs wish to avail to legal protection and formal entity status. 
- The points on identity seem to suggest a philosophical pivot away from purely anonymous structures to a pseudonymous model with the added assurances that offers users. 
- Critique of Klerosâ€™ ability to prevent collusion and offer rule of law based justice outcomes is a valid critique of financially incentivized Shelling Point justice models. Worth exploring further in Governauts to ideate on improved models for DAO mediation and dispute resolution adjudication. 
-  Casting 1Hive community and its social mission as a weakness is related to Governauts work on rewards systems and how a properly calibrated recognition system could use community to strengthen accountability in a large ecosystem with highly diverse user base.

â€œThe explicit overlay of political ambition to decentralised technologies introduces challenging dynamic when trying to establish â€œdecentralisedâ€ governance.â€ Is this really true?

Long ago, someone taught me that transaction is valuable when it increases the welfare of all the parties. I found this concept to be valuable and have used it ever since to negotiate all sorts of agreements. 

We have a bias toward centralized economic systems because we believe the welfare that results from transactions isnâ€™t increased in a way we deem to be equitable. Just recently a colleague insisted capitalism was governed by profit seeking which favors the capital owner. I retorted it was a choice. Every society decided for itself how the value created by a transaction, the welfare, is apportioned based on their subjective idea of fairness. More importantly, a societyâ€™s sense of legitimacy. 

With decentralized economic systems the community participants get to decide for the themselves how welfare is legitimately apportioned regardless of the societal and cultural norms of the IRL community they inhabit. 

Blockchain governance maintains its communityâ€™s sense of welfare legitimacy.

Wow, that is a super insightful question! Are you familiar with the Myersonâ€“Satterthwaite theorem? I believe it fails to encompass the concepts of welfare you described.

Transacting to equitably increase welfare is either a choice and / or a goal. I'm curious whether you agree with justice as fairness ~ kind of seems like governance as responsibility.

Legitimacy of welfare can be an extremely useful topic for discussion about benefits of decentralized economic systems. However, I'm not sure if participants make any decisions *regardless* of the societal and cultural norms in communities...

but perhaps in spite of or despite those norms? It could be considered quite desirable for some to be perceived to be doing exactly that, "regardless" of the ramifications, because that contrarian viewpoint is signaling a unique virtue in comparison to those around them.
Great point!

Ever heard people refer to themselves as GEers or IBMers or what have you? Those folks ascribe to a corporate culture which is distinct, if not separate, from the dominant cultural paradigm they usually inhabit.
We are all part of many different communities. All day long we transit from one to another and then back again.
Very true, no individual can actually be exempt from the membership of the broader collective
Must be a generational thing James. ğŸ˜
ğŸ˜„ğŸ˜„ğŸ˜„

I know I slip from one community to another all the time. Each of them have their cultural norms. However, I do this because my welfare - as well as that of others - is often increased through our social transactions. If this werenâ€™t the case, we would leave.
Or never return. But what motivates the state change? Is it cyclical? Is it selfish subconsciously knowing we derive some intrinsic benefit? Or is it necessarily mutual?
Those are all good questions. The answer is simply: thatâ€™s life.
Iâ€™m not familiar with Meyerson- Satterwaite theorem. Thanks for one more subject to deep dive into. My education never seems to end in this industry. ğŸ’•

text:
I think almost everyone will agree data is the new oil, and big tech companies are the ones extracting a disproportionate amount of the value from the publicâ€™s data. You know the restâ€¦ auction model, modern day â€œslaveryâ€, concentrated economic and political power, reality distortion,â€¦ The question we then have to ask is how do we use crypto to correct for this. 
My uneducated answer is yes. 
Put crypto between the data and the users of that data to redistribute value extraction in more equitable manner. Instead of big tech extracting value using an auction system which maximizes their revenues and very little in general way of costs, we should be striving to have a system which benefits the individual data owner. Everyone becomes their own Exxon or BP. Everyone then has a UBI based off of their own data.
Similarly, todayâ€™s data users have seen upward pressure on auction prices which is contrary to their business models. 
And, regulators around the world are challenged to correct these misalignments.
Is there a better way forward?
It is from this perspective that I have been thinking about the problem. Yesterday, I challenged
to think about this as well. However, everyone is welcome to do so.

Does anyone know of any studies/analysis done on % of active voter participation across different DAOs?

Perhaps cohorting further, across different blockchain verticals (I.E. Protocol, DeFi, NFT, Social)?

This is a subject of ongoing interest for me, and not of a single parameter offered, but a look at the lifecycle of participants and their contribution and utilization. Further look may lead to insights into population stratification, supporting benchmarking across organizational domains and specific instances.

Folks in business invest substantially into BI, watch and optimize their funnels all the time, with a promise of further improvements through ML/Big data.  They had to learn that exclusive focus on "vanity metrics", like a number of account sign-ups or page views, can easily distract and even divert from revenues and profits.

Crypto 'organizations' are apparently too new and immature yet, but the ones that will still be around and successful in 3-5 years will have to get there.

I'm neck deep in working on our DAO, but am curious as who is leading analytics/BI across all DAOs, especially those within Snapshot.

I feel like this could really be broken down into something practical. The following data/synthesis could be a useful starting ground:
- Snapshot Space (name/id)
- Some json mapping that enables to append metadata (Protocol, DefI, NFT, Social)
- Total Proposals submitted
- Total Voters, Total Holders / per Proposal (lookup tokens inside strategy utilized)

I did data engineering/analysis for mobile game companies for the last 4.5 years, and helped focus specifically on where the rubber meets the road.

I highly recommend people familiarizing themselves around this field, as mobile games are extremely competitive, can scale incredibly fast, and rely on very fundamental metrics/systems to reach escape velocity.

messages.text: I have always admired the pace of UI, storytelling and tech innovation in video games, though never worked in the field, as the workload and the hours are killer..

With DAOs, to me at least, the point is not to have the all too common "us vs. them" setup, like a commercial company does with the hoards of "users". Even with DAO-like crypto projects, the core founding team likely does not integrate fully with the multitudes of newly acquired members, who can remain more like "customers."

But such a stratification and limitations to mobility occur often enough in every type of non-commercial organization and grouping, which indicates even more basic behavioral mechanisms at play, than the profit motive or contractual and societal structures.

No direct experience with Snapshot yet. Only heard of independent DAO-specific analytics by Boardroom and by DeepDAO.
Not surprisingly, even for DAOs, they focus where most voiced interest is, valuations and price action.
I love the posts you bring us here!
Does any of this understand the ability of the decentralised community to steer AI towards good, as opposed to central authorities tendency to control for control purposes?
Game development is a grind house. Happy to have a strong footing in that industry, but moved past it.

Stratification occurs in all markets/organizations as those closest to the vision usually reap the benefits. Also, because assets and advantages tend to shift from the many, or are only available to a few.

This is a feature, not a bug. 

The question I think is how can we align incentives so we can use that for net-positive outcomes that benefit all participants.

"Competition is for losers."

Having said that, I feel like I have always found a way to navigate these inneficiencies.

If you are really engaged in fundamental outcomes and know how to apply leverage, you will cut through the noise and go far anywhere.

In other words, creating value & productivity vs. extracting value & rental seeking.

Over my career, I have managed to stand out just by focusing on a pretty narrow set of net-positive values.

Game design/dev as an example, is easy to stay ahead just by being market centric vs. ego centric. 

"Being true to the art" is a quick path to martyrdom, and focusing on those who share your echo chamber.

messages.text:
In its original form "reputation" referenced a widely held opinion, a consensus assessment of sorts, with "reputed" implying "thought of as being". Thus, reputation can be good or bad [ill repute], rather than a high or a low value of a single metric.

Tying individual compensation to popular opinion [popularity contest] is generally frowned upon, due to being easily manipulated and readily diverging from the economic value of the contribution, based on whether it can be maintained indefinitely, in presence of market forces.

Having thought about this a while, I conclude generally that a single cumulative metric, however derived, cannot reflect separate aspects of the worth of someone's participation, particularly considered over time. Contribution of some mix of resources and effort is not interchangeable with strong engagement. Making unique expertise or specialized access available, is yet another component.

Further, conflating aggregated level of rewards with due influence in making decisions is also likely to lead to misalignment.

The fact that the influences cannot be reduced to a single cumulative metric does not indicate that the dynamic cannot be investigated analytically or studied quantitatively, but only that it is not trivial.

messages.text: No worries ğŸ˜Š

Folks, I am happy to have found this group and see some familiar names, but also a whole bunch of new ones, with notable things to say.

I find myself somewhat disappointed, after more than three years of DAO cult-like excitement. A whole range of DAO types, all the ones not tied directly to on-chain assets and crypto industry investment, not only have not flourished, but showed few signs of liveness.

All the cause-based, community-centric, regional, common interest, alternative living, agricultural or trade coop, research, art, or education, either folded immediately or only lasted through the initial round of funding or bubbling excitement of original founders.

I call these "soft" DAOs, to borrow a term from commodity trading, and if such pursuits cannot be supported by DAO-like structures, then all the promises of DAOs changing the way humanity organizes and works are empty.

I suspect that current belief system around DAOs glosses over crucial issues, and for systemic reasons, while some axiomatic principles are largely wishful thinking.  Would anyone be interested in methodic application of critical rational thinking here, heavily borrowing from more established fields, to  identify and classify open issues and challenges to growth and sustainability of DAO-like structures?

I am collecting information and thoughts for an article "How DAOs Fail", but would prefer a more balanced and positive outlook, that takes the subject beyond a small batch of my personal experiences and opinions colored by emotion.

It's an important discussion.

How do various voting systems influence group behaviour?

We likely can't answer this yet until we see group destinies given their chosen voting systems.
You have much to contribute to this discussion!

For me, right now, three factors matter.

1) Token earning
2) Token exchange
3) DAO openness 

Point 1) is an essential human right, which must be supported.

Point 2) means eg we can feed ourselves and exercise choice. We might choose to spend tokens on governance matters or not. 

But if we don't like the voting systems, point 3) becomes critical, because we can exchange whatever we like and then walk away, joining a new DAO with different voting systems.

DAOs are trying to do what the military has already perfected decades ago. I feel like I could rant about this for days I'm just not sure if organization, communications and operations is as exciting for others as it is for me. 

I have some thoughts on what would support DAOs.

messages.text:
DAOs I've been involved in the past made no effort to assess and track the state of the "general population's" engagement, participation, contribution, satisfaction, whatever...

I feel that to be a huge barrier to understanding and optimizing DAO operational performance, ultimately affecting its continued success and longevity.

However, automated methods, using some mix of login / session records and SourceCred-style of comment / commit tracking, have obvious limitations, and are likely to become skewed through making a connection to public recognition or to compensation mechanisms.

Some may create a feeling of being creepy or otherwise impinging on individual preferences for the level of privacy and unfettered freedom of communication and participation.

Meanwhile, self-reporting assessments / surveys tend to suffer from participation by a minority of the contributors, potentially declining further through repeated application.  The turnout and thus the distribution of information, are likely not to be representative of the overall population, differing between the strata and also changing throughout the participant lifecycle and their level of satisfaction and engagement.

Experiences, observations, suggestions?

messages.text: Thanks Peter, we are adding two tools, Citizen's Island and UBI-Vault, to the DAO toolset, for making a parallel economy!

My concerns stem from now several observations of participant stratification in DAO-like structures, rather similar to what I have seen earlier in cause-based and advocacy non-profits.

There is a core group, where some are the original founders and their long-time buds. A number of them had served as a President or Vice or Treasurer over the years. Several may be variously compensated to be there, through the organization or as part of their employment or professional training elsewhere. Let's say there is a half dozen such, and about as many peripherally...

Then, there is a flow of new arrivals, several / month, a minority of whom somehow associates with the core group and are still around 3-6 months ago, down to a small fraction after a year or two.

If the organization has a broad outreach program or hosts events and regular open meetings, the influx can be much larger, but at least in my experience the "attachment" rate does not increase much, not in any proportion to the volume of the visitors.

The "core" may have a somewhat different demographic than the "visitors", distributed perhaps toward an older and variously higher bracket of the socioeconomic and educational range. "Us vs. then" attitude strengthens, as the core is oversubscribed and readily exhausted, and becomes frustrated by getting no help nor appreciation.

Meanwhile, the arrivals are confused or even taken aback by the established rituals in word and action, that may not even appear connected at this point. The few that make an attempt to connect and get involved may meet with indifference or even distrust, and are rarely supported through the process. The opinions and ideas that they voice may not even receive consideration and simply dissipate.

Less astute members of the core may even feel that the newcomers simply "do not know, haven't been around long enough, haven't paid their dues".
The most unfortunate part happens when the core participation starts to dwindle, as people inevitably move away, get otherwise occupied, experience and withdraw from conflicts within the contingent.
With no mechanism nor tradition of evergreening all levels of the organization, it may fold, and sometimes surprisingly quickly.

Audiences, yes for sure. Prospects and customers might be a subsequent stage, but in better cases supporting building towards that.

If noobs are not caught and supported, on entry, that is why interest fades, and why folk don't reach the level of contributor.

The majority of learning curves need support. Not everyone is like developers, willing and able to learn for themselves. I understand GitHub is formed over 50% from people who taught themselves.

Imagine if schools worked liked that! Or even if they encouraged us to work like that!

So the test of any organisation, including DAOs, including corporates, is do they support their members in being autonomous, and in their personal growth journey. An organisation with growing teams will have a much better chance of growing itself. Conversely, if a group doesn't support personal growth, folk will leave to grow somewhere more conducive.

A visiting prospective contributor cannot contribute unless proper connection is established.

The potential for contribution is established through the excellent open door policy. Not all DAOs see how to grasp that potential and make it material and rewarding.

It is good that many DAOs seek the in person connection through AMA sessions, but these have their limits, and are not all accessible.

Which leaves asynch, which can be a fruitful avenue for onboarding, but folk are less skilled in this area.

This is all learning curve territory. Switched on educators are a necessary component. Switched on corporates have hugely expensive corporate development systems, so expensive only Fortune 500 can typically afford them. Discord and some switched on DAOs could revolutionise that!

Thanks Roland, I'll watch and listen!

Do you have a link to support my enquiry, and a bigger picture of this work?

One thing I've learned after years of board-level participation in advocacy non-profits is that people want a choice in the type of recognition and rewards that they receive, and their preferences may be directly opposite.
These responses may give you an idea, "I don't want a gift card to X, never shop there; already have too many plaques; don't wanna be in a picture and have my name/face anywhere; this kinda money I make in a hour and this is an insult." 
Meanwhile, for others in the same group, every one of these choices was just perfect.

messages.text: You didn't mention Organisation, where there are one or more interesting tensions with autonomy?
"Organizations bind the views of Citizens with the views of communities." Does that make sense?

Hi Waka, although it may seem that focusing on "how daos fail" is negative, I believe it's crucial to not be too positive when critical, risk/weakness/threats are being assessed.

Builders have a tendency to be overconfident with their hypothesis, optimistic with their designs, and hopeful with traction. We underestimate how difficult something is, and overestimate our chances of success.

There are also examples of how focusing on solutions against very ambitious goals lead to great outcomes, but statistics (early stage - 70% of products don't establish product-market-fit, mid stage - some high % don't make it past the first 2 years), say otherwise.

I usually think of Jim Collins when I hear anyone talk about endearing companies, and he is probably one of the most knowledgeable people that comes up whenever I think of the subject (good to great, built to last).

Focusing on the risk/weaknesses/threats is how they have survived imminent failure.

So, I would personally love to read this angle first. And then hypothesize/asses constructive outcomes, based on this knowledge.

Aloysious, if you have specific resources to point in my direction, I am personally very interested in this angle. 

Organizational structure and ops has been built upon for generations. Similar to defi, gov, and many web3 sytems, we are building on existing, foundational knowledge.

Thanks for coordinating! Will try to be in attendance next week ğŸ™‚

Fascinating perspective! You inspired me to attempt articulating the following thought experiment in a new context. Previously, I used school systems with groups of teachers and their specific leaders, a.k.a. principals. Above that level of representation, local schools belong to a certain district, which is one part of the whole state / country.

The hypothesis: relying on a single principal (or a single district-level organization) actually creates inefficiencies, now that we have more capacity for asynchronous coordination.

Typically, decisions made in that context are budgetary. However, Iâ€™m curious whether a military context would help others understand the importance of pluralizations. Rather than using resource allocation as an example of the process to govern, maybe the idea of a war room could lend itself to this experiment:

Just imagine a president has the big red button, and they are surrounded by generals with necessary info pertaining to that decision (whether to press it). The question is why do we trust our â€œCommander in Chiefâ€ instead of the whole room? My answer is urgency. Some types of decisions require utmost efficiency, so there is not enough time (or any limiting factor) to effectively coordinate pressing multiple buttons.

There is a similar problem with each general representing various branches of the military (navy, army, etc) and their specific departments. How can they possibly communicate all the pertinent info available?

Hello, thanks for having me. I just finished reading about 10 days back and feel like I've found my group. I really appreciate the content and spirit here and yes I did complete the survey.

Im interested in learning/solving governance but have yet to actually engage with a dao. I've been interested in decentralization for about 20 years and really am a systems thinker. I do have a software company I'd like to convert to a dao because I believe it would be far better served as community driven. 

I also may have different perspctives on some of the issues mentioned but I really am here to learn as my ideas haven't been tested. My primary interests for governance are: 

1. distribution that is consolidation proof and attracts value added owners
2. faciliitating engagement
3. Governance that imitates a living being

While there are a lot of variables in DAO governance, it seems that efficiency in these will have a multiplier effect on most others.
Thank you for sharing! Iâ€™m curious to understand what interests you about facilitating engagement ğŸ™‚

text: Hi
10 days is a lot nowadays. Living beings and governance, that is a beautiful anapsychism (new word).

messages.text:
like mentioned above, without engaged voters, any decentralized system will fail. 

This means that a successful dao must have built in mechanisms for facilitating the engagement of the owner/voters. I see this as a funciton of four things: 

1. Proper distribution to prequalified owners (the idea being less of the right people is better than more of the wrong people)
2. Proper onboarding and ongoing education of those owners into a culture of engagement
3. Mechanisms that reward engagement proportionate to the quality of contribution
4. Effective curation/ease of access to information required to make informed engagement.

I think there may be a conditioned barrier to having engaged owner/voters which is apathy caused by the perception that their contribution doesn't impact their personal lives. This can be addressed with the above items. 

You might be intersted to know that my software company is acutally a novel approach to rewards. I firmly believe that positive reinforcement is the most effective way to modify behavior and found that existing systems don't actually utilize the criteria needed for influincing behavior through rewards.
it was a very satisfying read ğŸ™‚
Fascinating! Iâ€™d love to learn more about your software ~ what are the criteria needed for influencing behavior through rewards?

I ran a sensory deprivation center (seriously a deep systems thinker) for 11 years and realized many issues with how retention programs are structured, that led me to reward systems, but then realized that all reward systems are point-based which work for product businesses, but not service businesses because the calculus for service shifts costs to time, not unit production. That led to restructuring rewards based on time to fit how costs are born by the business. It was a very difficult sale to service businesses because most service busiensses have low business acumen which is why I think it is much better community driven. I do have a patent for my invention and would love nothing more than to see it thrive decentralized. But as I've dug in, I realize just how new dao governance and support reallly is which has led me to looking for groups intersted in growing that aspect.
Very cool! Glad to meet you along this journey ğŸš€ I wonder if there might be alien spaceship DAOs that live and run organically ğŸ›¸
lol. I don't count anything out these days
people told me lots of crazy things after they got out of the tanks
Is the reward for a single cell, or for a group of cells, or, 2 billion years later for a tissue, an organ, an organism, a group of organisms with a neocortex, a reward for surviving?  Or for joy?

how does one not affect the other? doesn't rewarding a part affect the whole and rewarding the whole affect the part...to differeing degrees, of course? and if a tipping point is reached, it creates positive feedback loops between the two.
I think this line of thinking perfectly fits dao governance
The "motivation" is missing~for the moment I think, , how can we make DAOs irresistible for the crowd?

im not gonna pretend I know solutions. I read above about having a lot of influx of energy that dissipated over the past couple years and know how hard these issues are to solve. I think those that have been in this space for 3 years are *bleeding* edge. Cutting edge is great, bleeding edge hurts.

With that said, in behavioral modification, inspiration leads to motivation, motivation leads to action, and action leads to habit. If there is a breakdown in any of these or in transition, a modification fails. This is easy to say in abstraction, much more difficult to apply to the real world. 

I know I am very inspired by the potential that DAOs have to reshape society. I firmly believe they can push wealth back down and distribute consolidated power. I think there is a rising potential for this same hope to inspire others as they find themselves more and more disaffected by a system that can't meet their needs. We have some work to do to get that message out and then to transform that inspiration into motivation. That can get people in, but the action must be facilitated in a way that leads to the habit of engagement.

that's a great article. there is still so much work to be done. I'm curious about all your thoughts on privacy. Do you think it is a required component, for some but not others, or not that significant?
Not only is privacy a human right, but also a public good!

I agree with privacy as a fundamental right, I am more considering it in a governance system. I am looking at cost/benefit analysis of privacy. I can see some DAOs, especially investment being very beneficial/necessity for privacy, but when it comes to reputation, especially as it extends beyond the dao itself, into the real world, privacy needs may break down or may be counterproductive.

 I know there are ways to verify without disclosing, but I'm thinking there may be good use cases for public disclosure. Consider social media. Reddit prefers privacy, twitter half/half, facebook mostly public and even if the controlling entity allowed privacy, many would still opt for public for various reasons.

messages.text: You can violate someone's privacy (obtain information), respect someone's privacy (get no information) but you cannot change someone's privacy. You are responsible for your theoretical and practical interpretation of your privacy. To be able to fine-tune your digital privacy settings (A can see this, B can see that) you should have a platform where this is possible, like our CI platform.

I was thinking some more about the war rooms / commander situation. 

There Isn't really a need for a commander. I believe that is hyper individualism built into the architecture. 

The more I reflect on commanders they made it so we all lost transparency. Many were great leaders but all of them took credit for the work of an entire organization. Everyone labored around making the commanders looks good and our whole careers were parades of establishing power and dominance over one another to ultimately climb to the top. Quite frankly when a decision is ever to be made or carried out I think 3 people present / representing a group should be a minimum. Not only good for accountability  but....so they cay support one another. 

Musings that crept through while driving for 6 hours.

Thanks for your great questions, this is a difficult one :) We, from the Citizen's Island project, are not sure what  to choose for an organization type .  A foundation in Switzerland, like the Commons Stack's foundation (

), can be useful for donations and grants. Or shall we join a DAO project for funding, or make our own DAO?  Suggestions welcome! Our project UBI-Vault will move to Switzerland because half of the global money is stored there, and so it is easier to donate legally to the UBI-Vault. Switzerland is the only country worldwide where people can donate and do not have to tell where the money comes from, as long as they can tell where it will be used for. On a functionality level, a Company Island (which is a Citizen's Island plus products and services) can make use of simple DAO components, made available bij the Commons Stack. In our upcoming CI pilot with 2000 companies it would be really helpful to have such tools available. A first tool can be a simple direct democratie module, allowing people to make proposals and to vote.

messages.text: For small and medium companies to survive we want to provide them with a Company Island where they can show their (sustainable) products and services. Citizens can upvote those products, companies with many upvotes will be found by surfing Citizens. Adding DAO tools, to support direct democracy, will  promote the DAO ideas,  we think.
